ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this to a student who has a very profound interest in the topic of frontiers and provinces along with a background in socio-political history and anthropological methodologies.

A highly dynamic and entertaining interdisciplinary course, this class was what I hoped it would be. I would absolutely recommend it, if only for the dynamic between the two professors. The numerous perspectives brought together into one seminar class allowed a much broader understanding of the premodern world. The result was a highly rewarding intellectual experience.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: The course forced me out of my comfort zone to work with both literary and visual sources for my final project. It taught me a lot about war and martial strategies, which I probably never would have learned otherwise! Also, being forced to think outside of my immediate field.. in terms of time period, culture, and nature of the evidence.. can always have a positive effect on future research!

The course enabled me to compare the Roman frontier with those of other civilizations, most notably China. Thus I could more easily pick apart exactly those qualities which differentiated Rome from other empires. Similarly, the class emphasized those aspects of frontier that are common across civilizations, providing a clearer picture of the process by which culture changes and evolves. This perspective will inform the way I think about the classical world going forward.
